title: Buka Stew Recipe
summary: Buka stew is a rich, smoky Nigerian tomato-based sauce served in roadside eateries (‘bukas’). Slow-cooked in palm oil with assorted meats, it’s perfect with rice, beans, yam, or plantain.
instructions: Boil blended tomatoes, peppers, and half the onions until thick.
Heat palm oil until slightly bleached.
Fry sliced onions in the oil, then add boiled pepper mix.
Fry for 20–30 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Add cooked meat, stock, crayfish, seasoning cubes, thyme, and salt.
Simmer for another 15 minutes until oil floats.

title: Nigerian Fish Stew
summary: A hearty Nigerian stew made with fresh or fried fish simmered in spicy tomato sauce. Commonly paired with rice, yam, or plantain.
ingredients: 6 medium fish steaks (tilapia, catfish, or mackerel)
instructions: Season fish with salt, pepper, and one seasoning cube. Fry lightly or grill.
Blend tomatoes, peppers, and onions, then boil until thick.
Heat oil, add chopped onions, and fry the boiled pepper mix.
Add curry, seasoning cubes, and salt.
Add fish and cook gently for 10–15 minutes to avoid breaking fish.

title: Efo Riro Recipe
summary: Efo Riro is a Yoruba-style spinach stew made with pepper sauce, assorted meats, and sometimes stockfish. Best served with pounded yam or rice.
instructions: Blend tomatoes, peppers, and 1 onion, then boil until thick.
Heat palm oil, add sliced onions, and fry boiled pepper mix.
Add meats, crayfish, seasoning, and salt. Simmer for 10 minutes.
Stir in spinach, cook for 3–5 minutes, and remove from heat.

title: Party Jollof Rice
summary: A smoky, rich Nigerian rice dish cooked in tomato-pepper sauce — a must-have at parties.
instructions: Blend peppers, tomatoes, and 1 onion; boil until thick.
Heat oil, fry onions and tomato paste, then add pepper mix.
Add curry, thyme, stock, seasoning cubes, and salt.
Add rice, cover tightly, and cook on low heat.
Stir occasionally until rice is cooked and slightly smoky.

title: Meat Pie Recipe
summary: Flaky Nigerian pastry filled with minced beef, potatoes, and carrots — perfect as a snack or light meal.
instructions: Mix flour, salt, baking powder, and butter until crumbly. Add water to form dough.
For filling, fry onions, add beef, potatoes, carrots, seasoning, salt, and pepper. Cook until tender.
Roll dough, cut circles, fill, and seal edges.
Brush with egg wash and bake at 180°C for 25–30 minutes.

title: Party Salad
summary: A colorful Nigerian layered salad with mayonnaise dressing — popular at events.
instructions: Arrange cabbage, carrots, cucumber, pasta, and sweet corn in layers.
Mix mayonnaise with condensed milk for dressing.
Top salad with sliced boiled egg. Chill before serving.

title: Efo Elegusi
summary: A Nigerian melon seed (egusi) and spinach stew — rich, nutty, and common in Yoruba cuisine.
instructions: Blend peppers, tomatoes, and onions; boil until thick.
Heat palm oil, fry egusi paste until crumbly.
Add pepper mix, seasoning, and salt; simmer.
Add spinach and cook for 3–5 minutes.

title: Fried Rice
summary: A colorful Nigerian rice dish stir-fried with vegetables, liver, or shrimp — a party favorite.
instructions: Boil rice in chicken stock with curry and seasoning until done.
Heat oil, stir-fry liver/shrimp, then add vegetables.
Add rice and stir-fry for 5–7 minutes.

title: Okro Soup Recipe
summary: A slimy, nutritious Nigerian soup made from okra pods, often eaten with fufu or eba.
instructions: Cook meats and fish with seasoning until tender.
Add palm oil, crayfish, peppers, and onions to stock.
Stir in chopped okra and cook for 5–7 minutes.

title: Peppered Chicken
summary: Fried or grilled chicken tossed in a spicy Nigerian pepper sauce — perfect for parties.
instructions: Season and boil chicken until tender. Fry or grill until golden.
Blend peppers and onion; fry in oil with seasoning and salt.
Toss chicken in pepper sauce until coated.

title: Fried Pepper Stew
summary: A deeply fried Nigerian tomato-pepper sauce served with rice, yam, or plantain.
instructions: Blend tomatoes, peppers, and onion; boil until thick.
Heat oil, fry mixture for 20–30 minutes until oil separates.
Add seasoning and salt, stir, and serve.

title: Gizdodo (Dodo Gizzard)
summary: A Nigerian mix of fried plantains and gizzard chunks tossed in spicy pepper sauce.
instructions: Boil gizzards with seasoning until tender, then fry lightly.
Dice and fry plantains until golden.
Blend peppers and onion; fry in oil with seasoning and salt.
Toss fried gizzards and plantains in pepper sauce.
